skill.name: creating-commands
skill.description:
Creates new Claude Code slash commands following best practices. Guides through command
structure, naming, arguments, and frontmatter. Use when user wants to create a command,
build a slash command, or asks about command best practices.

Creates new Claude Code slash commands following best practices. Guides through command

skill.author: BrendanShields

security_audit.summary: Pure documentation skill with no code execution capabilities. Contains only markdown templates and best practices guides for Claude Code slash commands.

content.value_statement: Build custom slash commands to automate repetitive tasks and standardize team workflows. This skill provides templates and best practices for commands that integrate with Claude Code.
actual_capabilities: Create commands with positional or all-arguments syntax
Build workflow commands that integrate with skills and agents
Apply naming conventions and validation checks
Define allowed-tools and argument-hint in frontmatter
Review existing commands against best practices
limitations: Does not execute bash commands or modify files directly
Requires manual placement of generated commands
Does not provide runtime execution of generated templates
Limited to Claude Code slash command format only

use_cases.title: Standardize team commands
use_cases.description: Create consistent commands for common workflows that all team members can use across projects.

use_cases.title: Automate repetitive tasks
use_cases.description: Build custom commands to automate testing, building, and deployment tasks specific to your project.

use_cases.title: Design command interfaces
use_cases.description: Design and document slash command patterns for plugins distributed to other users.

prompt_templates.title: Simple command
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a slash command named lint-check that runs npm run lint and reports findings grouped by severity.

prompt_templates.title: Command with argument
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a command named fix-issue that accepts an issue number, fetches it from GitHub, and implements a fix.

prompt_templates.title: Multi-argument command
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a command named create-component that accepts a component name and type (functional or class) as separate arguments.

prompt_templates.title: Workflow integration
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a deploy command that runs tests, builds the project, and launches a validation agent before deploying.

output_examples.input: Create a slash command named lint-check that runs npm run lint and reports issues
output: Validation passed: lowercase name, clear description, allowed-tools declared
To use: Run /lint-check in Claude Code

best_practices: Use verb-noun naming format with lowercase and hyphens only
Declare allowed-tools in frontmatter to scope permissions
Document argument-hint for commands that accept input
Keep prompts concise with clear step-by-step instructions
anti_patterns: Vague descriptions that do not specify what the command does
Missing allowed-tools declaration for commands requiring tools
Overly complex prompts that should be split into multiple commands
Hardcoded values instead of arguments for flexibility

faq.question: Where are commands saved?
faq.answer: Project commands go in .claude/commands/ and personal commands in ~/.claude/commands/

faq.question: What naming format should I use?
faq.answer: Use lowercase with hyphens only, such as run-tests or review-pr.

faq.question: Can commands accept multiple arguments?
faq.answer: Yes. Use $1, $2 for positional args or $ARGUMENTS for all input as one string.

faq.question: Are generated commands secure?
faq.answer: Commands run with Claude Code's existing permission model and tool restrictions.

faq.question: Why is my command not appearing?
faq.answer: Ensure the file is in .claude/commands/ and has proper markdown format with description.

faq.question: How is this different from skills?
faq.answer: Commands are simpler slash handlers while skills are more complex workflows with state.
